The new layoff era: Work is moving, not disappearing
description: Layoffs often signal a reorganisation of work rather than the end of work itself. The World Economic Forum’s Future of Jobs Report 2025 projects significant labour-market churn by 2030, with about 170 million roles created and 92 million displaced. Employers also expect major shifts in required skills, increasing the need for upskilling and redeployment as tasks change across industries and functions.

Watch: Indonesia grapples with deadly West Java landslide amid heavy rains
description:
Indonesian authorities have resumed search and rescue operations for at least 80 people missing after a deadly landslide struck a residential area in West Java. 

The landslip, triggered by heavy rainfall, killed at least 10 people and buried homes in Pasir Langu village, about 100 kilometres southeast of Jakarta. 

Rescue efforts have been hampered by unstable terrain and ongoing rain, preventing the use of heavy machinery.

title: 'Had a history of drug-related crimes': Dilraj Singh Gill shot dead in Canada, gang rivalry suspected
description: A 28-year-old Vancouver man with known gang links, Dilraj Singh Gill, was fatally shot in Burnaby on Thursday evening. Investigators believe this is part of B.C.'s escalating gang conflict, with a torched vehicle found nearby linked to the killing. Gill had a history of drug-related convictions and alleged ties to a group in conflict with the Brothers Keepers gang.

Nobel Laureate Roy Glauber says science is guesswork, not perfect logic
description: Roy Glauber, the physicist who won the 2005 Nobel Prize in Physics, challenged a core assumption about how science works. In interviews reflecting on his career, Glauber argued that real scientific breakthroughs rarely emerge from strict deduction. Instead, they grow out of intuition, guesswork, and sustained curiosity. His reflections offer a powerful career lesson for young scientists and educators, questioning how science is taught and how creativity truly enters research.

Why Microsoft is asking engineers to test Claude Code alongside GitHub Copilot
description: Microsoft is now having thousands of its software engineers test Anthropic's Claude Code alongside its own GitHub Copilot. This move signals growing confidence in AI coding tools, with even non-technical staff encouraged to experiment.  Nvidia's CEO also recently urged engineers to embrace AI coding assistants, highlighting a significant industry shift.

title: Accenture CEO Julie Sweet urges hands-on learning; cites 300 leaders trained
description: Accenture CEO Julie Sweet stresses that leaders must grasp AI to guide their companies through transformation. She advocates for leader-led training, citing a client whose 300 leaders had to directly use AI tools before progress was made. This hands-on approach, starting with top executives, is crucial for unlocking AI's potential and ensuring widespread adoption across all sectors.

title: ‘Doesn’t pass the sniff test’: Netflix rejects Paramount’s offer for Warner Bros Discovery
description: Netflix co-CEO Greg Peters dismissed Paramount Skydance's $108 billion bid for Warner Bros. Discovery as unrealistic, citing its heavy reliance on debt. He contrasted it with Netflix's more stable $82.7 billion all-cash offer, which is gaining traction with shareholders.  The potential merger faces significant Hollywood and regulatory scrutiny.
